title: ASL 3.1 ‚Äî Describing People üë§üß•
objectives: Describe people with compact frames using HAVE/WEAR and color + clothing
Ask/answer WHO? WHAT-LOOK-LIKE? WHAT-CLOTHES? with correct NMMs
Maintain consistent order (subject ‚Üí feature ‚Üí color) and steady signing space

vocab.def: WH-question; brows down; index circles near chin.
WH-question about appearance; brows down; LOOK + LIKE frame.
WH-question about clothing; brows down; CLOTHES sign + WHAT.
Bent hands move to chest (possession/feature existence).

vocab.term: RED ‚Ä¢ BLUE ‚Ä¢ GREEN ‚Ä¢ BLACK ‚Ä¢ WHITE ‚Ä¢ BROWN

vocab.def: Brows down for WH; brows up for YES/NO.

sections.heading: Warm-Up: Feature & Clothing Rows

media.alt: Icons: hair, glasses, hat, shirt, jacket, pants, shoes
media.caption: Mirror slowly; keep movements compact

sections.body: Drill features (**HAIR, GLASSES, HAT**) then clothing (**SHIRT, JACKET, PANTS, SHOES**). Reset to neutral space between items; keep palm orientation steady.

callouts.title: Eye Gaze
callouts.body: Look at your partner‚Äôs **face**; use peripheral vision for hands.

sections.heading: Model: Compact Description Frames
sections.body:
Use short, consistent frames:
‚Ä¢ **PERSON HAVE HAIR LONG.**
‚Ä¢ **PERSON WEAR SHIRT BLUE.**
‚Ä¢ **I LIKE JACKET BLACK.** Keep clauses 3‚Äì5 signs; avoid stacking too many details in one turn.

microCheck.q: Which order is clearest and easiest to keep consistent?

sections.teacherNote: Coach a tiny pause after SUBJECT. If adding two details, split into two clauses.

sections.heading: Questions: WHO? WHAT-LOOK-LIKE? WHAT-CLOTHES?
sections.body:
**WHO?** identifies; **WHAT-LOOK-LIKE?** asks for features; **WHAT-CLOTHES?** asks attire. Examples:
‚Ä¢ **WHO?** ‚Üí **STUDENT.**
‚Ä¢ **PERSON WHAT-LOOK-LIKE?** ‚Üí **HAVE HAIR SHORT.**
‚Ä¢ **PERSON WHAT-CLOTHES?** ‚Üí **WEAR SHIRT RED.**

callouts.title: Yes/No Follow-ups
callouts.body: ‚Äú**PERSON WEAR JACKET?**‚Äù (brows up) ‚Üí **YES / NO.** Then add detail: **JACKET BLUE.**

microCheck.q: Which face matches YES/NO questions like PERSON WEAR HAT?

sections.teacherNote: Encourage WH then Y/N follow-ups to refine details.

sections.heading: Partner Practice: Guess the Person
sections.body: A chooses a classmate/character card. A gives **2 short details** (feature + clothing color). B guesses using **WHO?**, **WHAT-LOOK-LIKE?**, or **WHAT-CLOTHES?** Swap roles.

callouts.title: Feedback Stem
callouts.body: ‚ÄúGreat order. Try a stronger WH-face on WHAT-LOOK-LIKE?‚Äù

microCheck.q: Best follow-up after a vague answer like ‚ÄúWEAR SHIRT‚Äù?

sections.teacherNote: Differentiate with printed prompt cards; allow seated options.

sections.heading: Mini-Showcase
sections.body: Record **10‚Äì15s** describing **one** person with **two** details + **one** question. Example: **PERSON WEAR SHIRT BLUE. HAVE HAIR LONG. WHAT-CLOTHES?**
sections.teacherNote: Offer privacy submission; caption should note where order consistency improved clarity.

items.q: Write an ASL gloss describing a person with two details (feature + clothing color) using a consistent order.

items.prompt: Which was harder‚ÄîWH vs YES/NO faces or keeping order consistent? What‚Äôs your practice plan?

reflectionPrompt: Submit your 10‚Äì15s clip (2 details + 1 question) and note how order consistency affected clarity.
summary: You can describe people with HAVE/WEAR frames, ask WHO/WHAT-LOOK-LIKE/WHAT-CLOTHES, and keep a consistent, compact order.
